title: For the Cheapskate Semi-Retiree, e-Readers Are a Revelation
text:
Text size

No one has ever accused me of being an early adopter.

For years, I balked at buying an electronic-book reader because I get most books free at the public library. We also have hundreds of books around the house, including favorites that I read often.

How could it get any cheaper than that?

Now that I’m a semi-retired grump with more time on my hands for shaving nickels, I realize how wrong I was.

Kindles and their ilk are great devices for cheapskates. You just have to use them right.

The wrong way is for impulse buys of books you wouldn’t buy otherwise.

The right way is to get books in the public domain on the cheap.

Amazon will sell you the entire works of Shakespeare, Dickens, and Twain for less than $1 apiece.

I’m not sure when I will next read Hamlet or Hard Times or Huckleberry Finn, but I now have them on my Kindle for whenever I want them, wherever I am. And for those who are really cheap, you can get free versions of many books online through Project Gutenberg.

The Kindle is even better for foreign authors, which is the actual reason I finally shelled out $99 for the device. I bought all the works of Jules Verne and of Alexandre Dumas in French for $2.99 apiece. In the past, I purchased used copies of French-language books from Amazon. It usually cost a good bit more than $2.99 for each book, plus I had to spend several dollars in shipping and handling, and wait for the book to arrive.

E-book readers are also great for minor authors who can be hard to find in public libraries. I bought electronic versions of the complete works of John Buchan, author of “The Thirty-Nine Steps,” and of H. Rider Haggard, author of “King Solomon’s Mines,” for 99 cents apiece.

We live in a world where free internet access has upended the livelihoods for musicians and writers, among others. That’s not good. But I see no harm in getting the works of authors who have been dead for decades, if not centuries, on the cheap.

Of course, the implications of electronic books go way beyond that. I’m writing this in a room lined with books. Some have followed my family around for decades.

If we go whole hog for electronic books, do we really need all these books? For that matter, do we need this room?

I put the idea of a book-free house to my wife, Clarissa. She gave me a look. She sighed. She spoke: “Yeah, we also won’t need beds. We’ll just be hanging from the ceiling like bats.”

I knew that Clarissa would react like this. But I can’t resist pulling her chain from time to time.

To be honest, I mostly agree with her. There is something comforting about being surrounded by books.

I don’t know if I could live in a house without them. If I can’t fall asleep, I can grab David McCullough’s wonderful biography of Truman or a Willa Cather masterpiece like “Death Comes for the Archbishop” or the best baseball book ever, “The Boys of Summer” by Roger Kahn. They’re all there.

That brings us to one of my favorite places in the world: the public library. Is there any better place to spend a rainy day than in one? Is there any better place to spend a sunny day?

Every library I’ve frequented has gems on its bookshelves ignored by much of the public. I live in fear that some efficient librarian will realize that I’m the only person who ever checks them out and chuck them. Fortunately for me, libraries go years without pruning their book collections.

How much is the e-book revolution shaking up public libraries? Less than you might think.

E-books make up just 11% of circulation in the public library in South Orange, N.J., my current hometown. And other non-print products, including videos and audiobooks, account for 6%.

Library Director Melissa Kopecky doesn’t see paper books disappearing soon. Paper books are more durable than electronic books, she says, and often cheaper for libraries because of new restrictions from publishers.

“Whatever is going to replace the paper book in the library doesn’t exist yet,” she says.

What’s more, many readers still prefer traditional books. “People who love paper just love paper,” she says.

Still, the world is changing. We recently went to visit friends in Geneva. In the past, I would have stuffed two or three tried-and-true books, either ones I owned or ones from the library, in my travel bag. This time, I brought the Kindle.

description: Semi-retired journalist Neal Templin isn’t an early adopter. But he’s happy to be a late adopter when the price is right.
